title: `format!` error messages point to wrong characters when using macro-generated literals

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: A-macros
labels.description: Area: All kinds of macros (custom derive, macro_rules!, proc macros, ..)

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-papercut
labels.description: Diagnostic error that needs small tweaks

body:
I tried this code:

```rust
fn main() {
    format!(concat!("{", "  f"));
}
```

I expected to see this happen:
```
error: invalid format string: expected `'}'`, found `'f'`
 --> src/main.rs:2:17
  |
2 |     format!(concat!("{", "  f"));
  |                      -      ^ expected `}` in format string
  |                      |
  |                      because of this opening brace
  |
  = note: if you intended to print `{`, you can escape it using `{{`
```

Instead, this happened:
```
error: invalid format string: expected `'}'`, found `'f'`
 --> src/main.rs:2:17
  |
2 |     format!(concat!("{", "  f"));
  |              -  ^ expected `}` in format string
  |              |
  |              because of this opening brace
  |
  = note: if you intended to print `{`, you can escape it using `{{`
```

Another more complicated example, is using `include_str!` (with a self-include to make playground testing easier):

```rust
fn main() {
    format!(include_str!("main.rs"));
}
```

Similar to https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/81070 it'd be very nice if this was able to point to the location in the included file, but if it can't it should probably have a simpler error message like "in external string included here".

### Meta
Tested on stable 1.51.0 and `1.53.0-nightly (2021-04-27 727d101561f9b1e81c62)`
